author: potuz
content:
<@!386593326402633741> 
> But what confuses me is how to determine WHEN the first whistleblow message happened. Take example of https://beaconcha.in/validator/4390#blocks . It says that this validator was "Slashed by 11111 at Slot 17,184, Reason: Attestation Violation". But how do I check when the first whistleblowing message actually took place?
OK, I'll describe the procedure detailed here, but in addition to what <@!364458974906548225> said, it would be better if you read about slashing before, so that you understand how the mechanism is, before trying to do data analysis on it. In this particular case, the block <https://beaconcha.in/block/17184#attester-slashings> contains 2 attester slashings. The validator you care about is 4390 which has a surrounding attestation. Attestation 1 is 531 --> 534 and attestation 2 is 532-->533. As the slashing can only happen after 534, we look at what was the slot in which 4390 was assigned in 534. This validator was assigned in 17097 in that epoch. However, the blockroot in the slashed attestation (you can see it's `0xe2f4ec7a975...`  corresponds to slot 17044. That means, the validator sent a vote for block 17044 as target in epoch 534, but that block is from epoch 532. This attestation says that it was in slot 17091, so it looks as though this validator thought it was suppose to attest in slot 17091, and attested for head in slot 17044, which may be due to a badly synced clock. The other attestation was in slot 17072 and looks like a good attestation 532-->533. Finally, the attestation 531-->534 is hard to know when exactly went out. We know it could not have been before slot 17044 cause the head vote is for that. Since the validator wasn't even assigned for slot 17091 my guess is that the clock was off, and the validator thought it was voting to target in 534 when in fact it was 532. This is supported by the fact that the attestation on 532 (which was for slot 17024) was missed. So the actual attestation that triggered
